PatientMatching.TEXT:
Record date: 2076-02-07
BOWNE EMERGENCY DEPT VISIT
GODWIN,YAIR 914-64-15-0 VISIT DATE: 02/07/76
This patient was evaluated and treated in conjunction with a
resident. I confirm the history and physical findings as
documented on the handwritten record.
HISTORY OF PRESENTING COMPLAINT: Briefly, this is a 70-year-old
patient with a history of mild weakness and easy fatigability who
was thought to be anemic with a hematocrit of 25 on evaluation at
an outside facility. He was referred here for further evaluation.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: GENERAL APPEARANCE: The patient is awake,
alert, and in no acute distress. VITAL SIGNS: Normal, with the
exception of a low grade temperature of 99.7. HEENT: Benign.
LUNGS: The breath sounds are clear. ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender.
LABORATORY EVALUATION: Hematocrit is determined to be 42. EKG is
normal. Chest x-ray shows no evident abnormality.
CONSULTATIONS (including PCP): The patient is seen in the
emergency department by the LMC physician as well.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS: Mild progressive unexplained fatigue.
DISPOSITION (including condition upon discharge): The patient is
ultimately discharged with followup for further investigation as an
outpatient. Condition upon discharge is stable.
___________________________________ JZ339/6381
HECTOR V. OBRYAN, M.D. HO78 D:02/07/76
T:02/07/76
Dictated by: HECTOR V. OBRYAN, M.D. HO78
******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2076-04-24
EDVISIT^91464150^Godwin, Yair^04/24/76^MURRAY, MARION OSCAR
The patient was interviewed and examined primarily by me.
CHIEF COMPLAINT: Right chest wall pain.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 70-year-old male
who presents to Bowne Hospital Emergency Department with no
one-week history of right-sided lateral chest wall pain. The
patient states the pain is worse with movement including
stretching, bending, and reaching. The patient states that
patient had slept with a hot water bottle on his right chest wall
for pain relief and had pain relief and was sitting in a chair.
His lying down on his right side was painful, and this morning,
sat up and while getting up, exacerbated the chest wall pain.
The patient discussed this pain with his primary care physician
during the past 2 weeks and who had been in agreement that it is
probable muscle strain. The patient denies any headache, visual
changes, and dizziness. Denies any neck pain. Denies any
left-sided chest pain. Denies any nausea, vomiting, diaphoresis,
or dyspnea. Denies any abdominal pain. He has been afebrile.
No cough.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Includes hypertension and non-insulin
dependent diabetes. The patient also has exposure to asbestos
and asbestos changes on CT scan previously.
SOCIAL HISTORY: Past tobacco, past ETOH, no IV drug abuse, lives
with his family, and he is retired.
FAMILY HISTORY: Noncontributory.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: As indicated in the history of present
illness, otherwise negative.
MEDICATIONS: See nursing note for full list of medications.
ALLERGIES: The patient has no known allergies to medications.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The patient is awake and alert in no acute
distress. Temperature 95.4, pulse of 67, respiratory rate of 16,
blood pressure 179/78, and O2 saturation 95% on room air. HEENT
is atraumatic. ENT: No infection. Pharynx is normal. Neck is
supple and nontender. Respiratory exam: Chest wall is tender.
Patient has reproducible, palpable right-sided posterior lateral
and anterior lateral chest wall tenderness. Normal breath sounds
bilaterally, no rales, rhonchi, or wheezing. Cardiac exam:
Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, and normal pulses throughout.
Abdomen is soft. The patient has some minimal amount of right
upper quadrant tenderness just subcostal at the infracostal
margin. No rebound or guarding. Skin is warm, dry, and intact,
no lesions, or rashes. Extremities are nontender. Normal range
of motion. No clubbing, cyanosis or edema. Neurologic exam:
Cranial nerves II through XII intact bilaterally. No motor or
sensory deficits.
LABORATORY DATA: Significant for white count of 10.6, hematocrit
of 38.5, platelets of 244,000. Sodium 138, potassium 4.1,
chloride of 105, bicarbonate 23, BUN 38, creatinine 1.9, and
glucose of 165. ALT of 11, AST of 16, amylase of 71, and lipase
61.
Given the fact that the patient had some right upper quadrant
pain and pain was radiating laterally to the right anterior
aspect, patient received a right upper quadrant ultrasound, which
was negative. No evidence of stones or gallbladder changes,
consistent with cholecystitis. The patient had a chest x-ray,
which showed no new changes from prior studies. No evidence of
******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
The patient received morphine IV, and subsequently received 2
Percocet tablets, and had resolution of his pain. Patient's case
was discussed with Dr. Rivers, who is the patient's primary care
physician, and who is in agreement to discharge the patient home
with pain medications and muscle relaxants. The patient is being
discharged home in satisfactory condition.
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS: Right chest wall pain.
______________________________
MURRAY, MARION OSCAR M.D.
D: 04/24/76
T: 04/25/76
Dictated By: MURRAY, MARION OSCAR
eScription document:8-7695417 BFFocus

Intern Admit Note
Patient: Godwin, Yair
MRN: 6894069
Admit Date: 8/01/76
PCP: Xavier Rivers (SHMC)
ID/CC: Shortness of Breath
HPI: Mr. Godwin is a 70 year old man with PMH of HTN, hyperlipidemia, DM type II, chronic back painand empyema in remote history, who presented to the ED by EMS after awakening from sleep at approx 3:00 am with acute shortness of breath and back pain. Pain was not shooting toward back, but radiated to the left shoulder. Accompanied by nausea and vomiting X 1, diaphoresis. No chest pain. Has never experienced such awakening previously. No orthopnea or LE edema. No fever or cough. No change in bowel habits. No blood per rectum or melena.
In ED, vital signs as follows: afebrile, BP 195/77, HR 72, RR 22, 98% on RA. Received ASA and lasix, NTG without effect, some morphine and ativan with better effect, and hydralazine IV and then PO.
PMH:
-NIDDM - on metformin and pioglitazone
-Hypertension - chronically elevated on therapy, per patient runs in 150-160 range/80. On atenolol and irbesartran
-hyperlipidemia
-History of asbestos exposure while a community organizer, corresponding pleural changes on CT
-psoriasis
-chronic back pain
ALL: NKDA
MEDS:
-Lasix 20 mg po qd, atenolol 100 mg po bid, glipizide 5 mg po qam, 10 mg po qpm, simvastatin, irbesartan 150 mg po qpm, lansoprozole 30 mg po qd, pioglitazone
FH: -Non-contributory
SH: -Retired worked as
-ETOH: one glass of wine per night
-TOB: remote
-IVDA:none
ROS: No F/C/S/N/V/D/hematochezia/hemoptysis. No CP/palps /LE edema. No change in appetite or weight. No cough, sore throat, rash. No pain. No rashes.
EXAM:
V/S: T 97.6, HR 56, BP 148/64, RR 22, 98% on 2L, 94% RA
Gen: cantankerous, conversant, obese, lying in bed in NAD
Skin: no rash/lesions/bruises
HEENT: NCAT, PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, o/p pink and clear, moist mucosa, normal dentition
Neck: supple, FROM, thyroid not palpable, JVP at 5 cm
Pulm: symmetric chest, CTAB, no egophony, no tactile fremitus
CV: NR RR S1, S2, II/VI systolic murmur, PMI not palpated
Abd: obese, atraumatic, NT, ND, +BS, no HSM, no striae, ventral hernia present on valsalva
Back: Paraspinal tenderness, minimal spinal tenderness at approx t10
Ext: no edema, clubbing or cyanosis, warm, pulses weak but present
Neuro: AAOX3, MS agitated, CN III-VIII intact, Moves all four extremities, Sensory intact. DTR's 2+ and symmetric in bilat LE and UE. Toes down bilaterally.

EKG:
Old left bundle branch block, normal sinus 66.
CXR:
FINDINGS:
No infiltrates or evidence of CHF is present. There is a three cm
mass in the right lower lung. This was shown to be rounded
atelectasis on chest CT. Pleural changes are consistent with
asbestos related pleural disease.
IMPRESSION:
Asbestos related pleural disease
Right lower lobe mass shown to be rounded atelectasis on chest CT.
CT:
CT Chest
FINDINGS:
No comparison. The aorta is of normal caliber. There is
atherosclerotic calcification of the aorta. Classic arch anatomy
is present.
Bilateral pleural calcific plaques are demonstrated consistent
with asbestos related pleural disease. In addition, in the
posterior segment right lower lobe there is 2.7 cm mass. The mass
has a linear pleural attachment adjacent to pleural plaques.
There is also present swirling vessels around the mass and volume
loss. The findings are consistent with rounded atelectasis. A
smaller focus of rounded atelectasis is present in the left lower
lobe.
Coronary artery calcifications present. No mediastinal or hilar
or axillary lymphadenopathy is present. There is no
supraclavicular adenopathy.
The osseous structures are unremarkable.
Please see dictated abdomen report.
IMPRESSION:
1. Normal caliber aorta please see MRA report regarding
evaluation of dissection.
2. Bilateral rounded atelectasis and asbestos related pleural
disease.
WMC MRA AORTA + & 01-Aug-2076 09:10
REPORT:
This study was reviewed with Dr. Upshur.
MRA OF THE THORAX WAS WITH AND WITHOUT GADOLINIUM.
Technique: Standard departmental MRA protocol of the chest and
upper abdomen was performed with and without gadolinium. 3-D
images were obtained and interpreted.
Findings:
There is a three vessel aortic arch. There is no evidence of a
flap within the aorta to suggest a dissection. The takeoffs of the
great vessels are normally patent. There is no evidence of
aneurysm.
The celiac artery and SMA are patent. There are single renal
arteries bilaterally. There is mild narrowing of the proximal
right renal artery. The left renal artery is patent.
IMPRESSION:
Unremarkable MRA of the thoracic aorta, without evidence of
dissection or aneurysm.
Mild narrowing of the proximal right renal artery.
____________________________________________
A/P: This is a 70 year old man with acute shortness of breath and back pain.
1. Cardiology - Will rule out for MI
Received ASA, SLNG, Lasix, beta-blocker in ED
Cardiac monitor, cycle enzymes
On atenolol, irbesartan as outpatient; will continue hydralazine for better management.
2. Renal - cr 1.8, appears close to baseline, consistent with chronic renal insufficiency, likely due to hypertensive disease
Will continue to follow
3. Endo - diabetic, non-insulin dependent
SS insulin, will convert to NPH once daily requirement is clear
4. Musculoskeletal - history and present complaint of chronic back pain, low to mid-back
Percocet for pain relief as NSAID contraindicated in CRI
5. Psych - volatile personality, significant anger toward doctors after wife's death 8 years ago
Will attempt to minimize aggravating situations
6. FEN
Repleted phosporus
7. Prophylaxis
Ambulating, on nexium.
8. Dispo
Home after acute cardiac workup complete; will have further risk stratification done through Shenandoah Hospital.
___________________________
Vera Winn pager 12081
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2077-03-31
Harper Hospital Intern Admission Note
Pt: Godwin, Yair
MR# 6894069
Admit Date: 3/31/77
PCP: Rivers, Xavier (Westlake-Shenandoah Hospital)
CC: chest pain
HPI: 71M hx DM, HLP, HTN, p/w chest pain. Pt reports having markedly reduced right eye visual acuity this evening, subsequently became increasingly anxious and nervous and developed chest tightness across chest at level of xiphoid. Intermittently had sharp pains in same distribution, reaching 5/10 in severity. Associated nausea and dry heaving, only briefly SOB. No associated lightheadedness, diaphoresis, or palpitations. Called daughter who then called Shenandoah Hospital emergency line, then called MVH and came into their emergency room where he was referred to WMC ER secondary to chest discomfort. Symptoms had resolved by time of being seen in WMC ER.
Of note, pt admitted to LMC (9/76) for acute onset SOB/CP. At that time, had negative PE protocol CT and adeno-MIBI. Just prior to that was admitted to WMC for similar symptoms and had negative dissection protocol CT at that time. At baseline, walks up to a mile without symptoms, also climbs stairs without symptoms.
In ER, vitals: T 98.2, P 69, BP 180/79, RR 18, 98% RA. Tx ASA 325mg, lopressor 25mg PO/5mg IV. Pain-free while in ER and transferred to floor in stable condition.
PMH:
DM-2
HTN
GERD
TURP
DJD of the spine
Chronic back pain
Hypercholesterolemia
Psoriasis
Chronic renal insufficiency
Macular degeneration
-reports having attack in 2/77, characterized as having acute vision blurriness, told at MVH he had macular degeneration
Adenosine-MIBI (9/76):
The ECG response to Adenosine was non-diagnostic. The scan results demonstrated no evidence of ischemia and/or scar. EF 54%.
Medications:
Glipizide 5mg po bid
Atenolol 100mg po bid
Irbesartan 150mg po qd
Pioglitazone 30mg qd
Lasix 20mg qd
Simvastatin 20mg qd
Aspirin (just started 1wk ago)
Vertigo
Gait disturbance
-thought secondary to peripheral neuropathy
Allergies: NKDA
SH: Patient is widowed and lives alone. He quit smoking 30 years ago and denies alcohol use. He is a retired community organizer. Known prior asbestos exposure.
FH: Unknown
Exam: VS T 97.5 P 62 BP 152/69 RR 20 95% 2L
Gen: NAD, anxious. Pain-free. A&Ox3.
HEENT: EOMI. No nystagmus. MMM.
Skin: No changes.
Neck: Supple. Brisk carotids, no bruits.
Chest: CTAB.
CVS: RRR. 2/6 early systolic murmur, maximal at RUSB, no radiation to carotids.
Abd: Obese, protuberant. Normoactive bowel sounds. Non-tender.
Extr: 2+ DP pulses. No edema.
Neuro: Markedly decreased visual acuity of right eye, otherwise CN 2-12 intact. Strength 5/5 throughout, sensation intact.

RBC 4.15 L (4.50-5.90) mil/cmm
PLT 227 (150-350) th/cumm
MCV 85 (80-100) fl
MCH 30.0 (26.0-34.0) pg/rbc
MCHC 35.4 (31.0-37.0) g/dl

DIFFERENTIAL REQUEST RECEIVED
Diff Method Auto
Poly 83 H (40-70) %
Lymphs 13 L (22-44) %
Monos 2 L (4-11) %
EOS 2 (0-8) %
Basos 0 (0-3) %
Imaging:
CXR (3/31/77): No acute process
EKG: NSR. LBBB. 1mm STD I/II/aVf/V5-6. 2mm STE V1-3. TWI I, biphasic T-wave V5-6. (No change from prior ekg)
Impression: 71M hx DM, HTN, HLP, p/w chest pain likely GI related and not cardiac in origin.
Plan:
1. chest pain: Unlikely cardiac in origin given negative EKG, recent normal stress test, and atypical nature. Likely GI related as pt with dry heaving around time of chest tightness.
-cont asa, simvastatin, atenolol, irbesartan, and lasix
-repeat EKG in AM
-cycle cardiac enzymes, telemetry
-check lipid panel
-maalox prn
2. decreased visual acuity: Most likely worsening macular degeneration given recent chronic history of symptoms. Absence of pain makes retinal vascular occlusion very unlikely, no other neurological symptoms to indicate CVA.
-refer pt back to MVH once ruled out for MI
-consider I- CT if more neuro symptoms develop to r/o acute stroke
3. Diabetes: -check lipid panel, hemoglobin A1c
-RISS, glipizide
-hold pioglitazone (not in formulary)
4. proph: nexium, heparin
Full Code

**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2081-08-07
Date 08/07/2081 WMC VASCULAR SURGERY ADMISSION NOTE
Patient: Godwin, Yair
MRN: 91464150
Attending: Orellana
HPI:
CC: newly developed vision deficit in the L lower quadrant of the L eye
HPI: Patient is a 75 y/o M, a former smoker, with Hx of multiple medical problems including macular degeneration in the R eye, CAD, NIDDM, HTN and hypercholesterolemia. A month ago he first noticed what he describes as “blue floaties” in the LLQ of his L eye’s visual field. He then saw his ophthalmologist at the Shenandoah Hospital in Parchman who concluded that this is not due to macular degeneration. He denies having headaches or any other symptoms at that time. He denies similar episodes of “floaties” in the past and he has no Hx of headaches, disarthria, motor deficits, sensory loss and has never been hospitalized with a stroke or TIA. He recalls having “high kidney function” in the past, but does not recall details. His PCP arranged for an U/S evaluation, which was done on 8/05/81 and showed 80-85% stenosis of the L proximal ICA. Patient has had surgeries in the past and had no adverse effects to anesthesia administration. He considers himself fit and in good shape.
PMH:
- CAD
- CHF
- NIDDM
- macular degeneration
- HTN, hyperlipidemia
- impotence
- COPD and empyema R lung 15 years ago
- abdominal hernia
- spinal stenosis and chronic neck pain (developed after MVA)
- arthritis and chronic L shoulder pain
- BPH
- asbestosis
- GERD
- migraines
- PNA
- psoriasis
PSH:
- s/p L knee replacement (2079)
- TURP (2075)
Meds on admission (patient does not know meds, below is per MVH records):
1. Atenolol 100 MG PO BID
2. Glimepiride (Amaryl) 1 MG PO QD
3. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 MG PO QD
4. Irbesartan (Avapro) 150 MG PO QD
5. Lisinopril 40mg mg PO QD
6. Omeprazole 40 MG PO BID
7. Pioglitazone (Actos) 30 MG PO QD
8. Simvastatin (Zocor) 40 MG PO QHS
9. Tamsulosin (Flomax) 0.4 MG PO BID
10. Lorazepam (Ativan) 0.5 MG PO QHS prn Insomnia
11. Finasteride 5 mg PO QD
12. Fluticasone Nasal Spray 2 SPRAY NAS BID
13. Multivitamin With Betacarotene (Ocuvite) 1 TAB PO QD
Allergies: Levofloxacin (pedal edema)
SH: The patient has a 60-pack year smoking history (quit smoking in 2063). He drinks ~ 3 glasses of wine per year. He is a widower, has three children and lives with his daughter in Lyndonville. He is a retired community organizer.
FH: There is no Hx of strokes. His mother passed away from at 90 (no significant medical problems) and father at 66 from MI.
PE:
T 95.7 P 74 BP 181/93 RR 24 O2 Sat 97%RA
Gen: NAD, well developed and appears younger than his stated age
Neck: prominent neck musculature, trachea midline, no masses or LAD, no signs of previous surgeries, no carotid bruits appreciated
CV: RRR, + S4
Pulm: CTAB
Abd: soft, non-tender, midline hernia present, no HSM
Ext: no femoral bruits appreciated; 2+ femoral, 2+ DP and 2+ PT pulses bilaterally; BL ankle edema (trace)
Neuro: cranial II-XII grossly intact, 5/5 motor strength and sensation bilaterally, cerebellar function intact
LABS:
BMP: 140/ 4.3/ 105/ 29/ 39/ 1.95/ 155
CBC: 8.58/ 38.6/ 265
Coags: 13.8/ 27.3/ 1
Blood bank sample sent
Radiology/Studies: Chest PA and LAT (8/07/81): Prelim read – costophrenic angles are blunted bilaterally, hazy opacities present bilaterally with R>L, cardiomegaly, trachea is midline; this appearance is comparable to previous CXR (2/81)
EKG (8/07/81): Sinus, rate ~ 70, wide QRS (LBBB), St segment elevation in v1-v3 seen on previous EKGs, overall comparable to baseline
Carotid Duplex U/S (8/05/81): RIGHT Carotid Artery Plaque Surface CA++ Velocity % Stenosis CCA Prox no plaque 69 CCA Mid no plaque 75 CCA Dist no plaque 66 ICA Prox hyperechoic homogeneous mild irregular 135 25-49 ICA Mid hyperechoic homogeneous smooth 108 25-49 ICA Dist hyperechoic homogeneous smooth 65 1-25 ECA hyperechoic heterogeneous mild irregular 97 <50
LEFT Carotid Artery Plaque Surface CA++ Velocity % Stenosis CCA Prox no plaque 78 CCA Mid no plaque 71 CCA Dist no plaque 52 ICA Prox hypoechoic homogeneous 427 80-85 ICA Mid hypoechoic homogeneous 150 50 ICA Dist 118 ECA hyperechoic homogeneous mild irregular 90 <50
A/P: 75 y/o M with multiple risk factors, presenting with amaurosis fugax of 1 month in duration in the setting of significant L ICA stenosis, as determined by U/S. His Sx most likely due to the observed stenosis. He is pre-op for L CEA for tomorrow. N: no issues CV: continue home meds; P: no issue; follow up official read of CXR GI: diabetic diet; NPO midnight GU: IVF after midnight Heme: start ASA 325 QD Endo: RISS ID: no issues Labs: Chem7, CBC, Coags, type and screen Other: patient consented
_____________________ Taylor Otero FSM IV (42745)
--
Patient seen and examined. Agree with above student note. In brief, 75yM with PMH significant for DM, HTN, high cholesterol, and macular degeneration who presents with recent onset of intermittent, transient ‘blotches’ in left eye. Carotid US evaluation showed left sided velocities consistent with 80-85% stenosis of left proximal ICA. He is admitted pre op for operating room tomorrow. Home meds with exception of oral antihyperglycemics will be resumed. See detailed plan above.
Discussed w/ Arthur Tisdale, chief resident, who agrees w/ assessment and plan.
________________
Virginia Roman
PGY-2
28793
